0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Adenocarcinoma in situ of cervix; Prophylaxis: (through 26 years and previously unvaccinated) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months
  • Adenocarcinoma in situ of cervix; Prophylaxis: (through 25 years) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1, and 6 months
  • Cervical cancer; Prophylaxis: (through 26 years and previously unvaccinated) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months
  • Cervical cancer; Prophylaxis: (through 25 years) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1, and 6 months
  • Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, Grade 1, 2, 3; Prophylaxis: (through 26 years and previously unvaccinated) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months
  • Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, Grade 1, 2, 3; Prophylaxis: (through 25 years) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1, and 6 months

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Adenocarcinoma in situ of cervix; Prophylaxis: (9 years or older) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1, and 6 months, or at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months
  • Cervical cancer; Prophylaxis: (9 years or older) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1, and 6 months, or at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months
  • Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, Grade 1, 2, 3; Prophylaxis: (9 years or older) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1, and 6 months, or at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Adenocarcinoma in situ of cervix; Prophylaxis
  • Cervical cancer; Prophylaxis
  • Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, Grade 1, 2, 3; Prophylaxis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: allergic reactions, severe (eg, anaphylaxis), to any component of the vaccine

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• acute illness with or without fever, moderate or severe; defer vaccination unless the benefit of protection outweighs the risk of an adverse reaction
  • latex sensitivity; tip cap and/or rubber plunger of prefilled syringes contain dry natural latex rubber
  • pregnancy; not recommended; if pregnancy occurs after starting vaccination series, delay remainder of series until pregnancy complete
  • syncope, sometimes associated with tonic-clonic movements and other seizure-like activity, has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • vaccine hypersensitivity; review immunization history and assess risks and benefits prior to administration
  • report suspected adverse events to GlaxoSmithKline at 1-888-825-5249 or to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) at 1-800-822-7967 or www.vaers.hhs.gov

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Erythema at injection site (48.4%), Injection site pain (91.9%), Swelling at injection site (44.3%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Gastrointestinal symptom (27.9%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia (20.7%), Myalgia (48.8%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (53.4%)
  • Other:Fatigue (54.6%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Syncope
  • Dermatologic:Erythema multiforme
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Other:Angioedema

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: development of IgG neutralizing antibodies against HPV L1 capsid proteins generated as a result of vaccination

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intramuscular
  • shake vial or syringe well before use
  • administer IM in the deltoid region of upper arm; do not administer IV, subQ, or intradermally

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: syncope, including tonic-clonic movements and other seizure-like activity; for 15 minutes after administration

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Warn patient that the tip cap and plunger of the need≤ss prefilled syringes contain dry natural latex rubber that may cause allergic reaction in patients with latex sensitivity.
  • Advise patient that vaccine does not actually treat cervical cancer or other diseases that are caused by human papillomavirus.
  • Drug may cause fatigue, headache, myalgia, arthralgia, gastrointestinal symptoms, and pain, redness, and swelling at the injection site.
  • Inform patient that drug is given in 3 doses at 0, 1, and 6 months.
